title: Why doesn't Eric Clapton like the Beatles? - Quora

response.answer_text: The Beatles are gone. They ended in 1970. So how he feels about them has likely changed and isn’t relevant. Why didn’t Clapton like the Beatles in the early 1960s? Because in the early 60s they were the most over hyped band in the world. While they were unquestionably a very talented band, there’s no way they could possibly live up to the hype and how they were being marketed at the time. I doubt Clapton was the only person in the music business who despised this and them, the way they were being portrayed as if they floated six inches off the ground when they walked. I doubt anyone in the music business who wasn’t making a lot of money off the Beatles liked the Beatles. Would he have joined the band or not in 1969? There are good reason for either decision. Cons: The Beatles had stopped touring a few years before and any gig with them was likely going to be recording only. Touring is where the bulk of the money for recording artists is in the music business. He likely would have been an salaried employee not a member of the band. The Beatles were on a downwards trajectory. Lennon clearly wanted out and wanted a solo career. Clapton joining would not have changed that. So he likely would have gotten only one or two albums out of the deal. It was not going to be a long term relationship. Pros: It would have increased his stature in the music business. He would have been paid a lot of money. Rumor has it it’s easily convertible to cocaine. His friendship with Harrison is irrelevant. People have screwed their friends over for a lot less money and for a lot less fame. Disclosure: I’m not a big Beatles fan. I find their music way too pop oriented. Unlike the Rolling Stones who were also blues fans, the Beatles were never able to capture the spirit of the blues in their own compositions, like the Rolling Stones can do. I’m also not a huge fan of Clapton. I think when he’s covering Robert Johnson, he’s incredible but that’s mostly Johnson’s material. But his other stuff, especially his solo material, doesn’t do much for me. For a blues aficionado, he isn’t able to capture it’s spirit in his own compositions.

I don’t think Clapton ever really “disliked” the Beatles Clapton said in an interview he used to listen to the Beatles on a radio channel which played Beatles music every week, with the actual quote from the interview below: Clapton - “They had a radio show called “Pop Go The Beatles” once a week” Reporter - “And you listened to them?” Clapton - “Yeah” So using this evidence, I don’t really think Clapton disliked The Beatles as of such. After all, he was very close friends with lead guitarist of the Beatles George Harrison and collaborated in “While My Guitar Gently Weeps” But the next part of the interview takes an interesting turn, as the reporter asked Clapton whether he aspired to be like the Beatles, Clapton responded with this: “No. Not at all.” You may ask why he chose to say that? Well, it has everything to do with his musical orientation, as he explains in the next part of the interview: “Even from my earliest recollection of that, that was too poppy.” “By the time they came around I was already deeply ensconced in hardcore blues.” “I was becoming a purist, straightfast.” So by the time Clapton heard the music of the Beatles, he was already too engaged in the blues music scene to fully appreciate and like the pop numbers of the Beatles. In my opinion, I think Clapton has nothing against The Beatles, it’s just too much of pop for him.
